reasoning: The critique targets the paper’s Section 3 formal framework (completeness + vNM axioms + cardinalization), which is a meaningful support for the paper’s “most plausible views are fussy” conclusion, but not the whole argument (Section 2’s fragility/examples don’t rely on vNM-style comparability). So centrality is moderate. The refutation strength is low because (i) the paper explicitly flags that not all moral views allow quantitative comparisons, (ii) restricting to vNM-representable ‘betterness over prospects’ is a methodological choice rather than an unargued hidden premise, and (iii) showing some moral theories are outside the model doesn’t establish that easy-eutopia becomes likely under them. Correctness is mixed: it’s true the analysis excludes incompleteness/incommensurability and many Kantian/pluralist frameworks, but it’s overstated/partly wrong to claim this “implicitly privileges consequentialist aggregation,” since vNM representability doesn’t entail consequentialism and the paper notes this. The critique is fairly clear, mostly on a single methodological objection, with some rhetorical dead weight (“biased… marginalizes dissent”) that doesn’t add argumentative force.
title: Cardinal utility assumptions exclude pluralist and incommensurable value frameworks
